prompt.preamble: We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences. In this activity, we're going to be looking at different strings of text and you'll be deciding if they look like they could be an email address or not. For example, most people would agree that "username@domain.com" looks like an email address, while "n12z5lFEN4" does not. However, the rules for what can be an email address can be very unusual, so what we're really interested in is your intuition on what an email address could look like. Important: We are not asking you to determine the rules for a *good* email address, or a *real (non-spam)* email address. We are simply asking about your intuition as to why certain strings look like email addresses and certain strings do not. Tip: in an email such as username@cs.stanford.edu, "username" is called the local-part of the email, while "cs.stanford.edu" is the domain. Furthermore, "cs" is a subdomain, and "edu" is a top-level domain.
prompt.task_description: your intuition of what makes email addresses look like email addresses
prompt.noninteractive_task_description: Try to be as detailed as possible. For example, if you were writing a regex that accepts only email-address-like strings, what might that regex look like?
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of email addresses, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your email preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following strings look like reasonably well-formatted email addresses or not: "yes" if they do, "no" if they don't.

conversation_history.message: Should an email address contain at least one period (.) after the @ symbol?
Yes because it means it's from a website that has been established.
Should an email address start with a letter or a number, and not a special character like a period (.) or an underscore (_) ?
Sometimes an underscore is acceptable, but most likely a period is suspect. Letters are usually the best way to start.
Should an email address contain at least one @ symbol to separate the username from the domain?
Yes because the @ will let you know that it's from a website.
Should an email address end with a top-level domain (like .com, .net, .org) after the last period?
Most likely because you know that it's from an official email account.
Should an email address be allowed to contain special characters (like !, #, $, %, &, *, etc.) in the part before the @ symbol?
Yes but it doesn't look as trustworthy or professional.
Should an email address be allowed to contain consecutive periods (like ..) in the part before the @ symbol?
No because it's too hard to remember all the dots.
Should an email address be allowed to contain special characters (like !, #, $, %, &, *, etc.) in the part after the @ symbol?
Sure but it doesn't look as trustworthy
Should an email address be allowed to contain numbers in the part after the @ symbol?
Yes if the website the email is from has numbers in it.
Should an email address be allowed to contain hyphens (-) or underscores (_) in the part after the @ symbol?
Sure because there are lots of websites with hyphens in them.
Should an email address be allowed to contain spaces anywhere in it?
Yes but only if the space is delineated with an underscore.
Should an email address be allowed to contain more than one @ symbol?
No it just looks like a typo.
Should an email address be allowed to contain uppercase letters?
No because capitalization can be confusing to remember.
Should an email address be allowed to contain more than one period (.) in the part after the @ symbol?
No because it looks like a typo

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn what rules a user believes to be a valid email address format must adhere to (e.g. for developing a regex format checker).

Previous questions:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative yes/no question that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Make sure your question addresses different aspects of the regex than the questions that have already been asked. At the same time however, the question should be bite-sized, and not ask for too much at once. Phrase your question in a way that is understandable to non-expert humans; do not use any jargon without explanation. Generate the yes/no question and nothing else:
